column1: What will President Biden’s approval rating be as of 31 March 2022, according to FiveThirtyEight?
column5: ['Lower than 40.0%', 'Between 40.0% and 45.0%, inclusive', 'Higher than 45.0% but lower than 50.0%', 'Between 50.0% and 55.0%, inclusive', 'Higher than 55.0%']
column6: ['US Politics']
on a downward trend - but still above 40% - unless there is a severe drop, dont' see it dipping below 40%
Recent polls shoiw approval dropping - Last ones show it at 40% - so right on the line between the two lowest possibilities in the survey.

No reason to expect a major shift given how little events this year have moved it, plus this is a weighted average so I'm guessing new info can't move it much even if there were a swing. Nothing is ever a hundred percent but I think the chances of other buckets are <1%
with 4 days remaining - 538 reporting low 40's but mid-bucket - all of march to date has been above 40% so high probability of maintaining throughout the month
second bucket seems virtually certain
Why does GJO not offer sub-1% inputs?
Recent spontaneous remarks in Poland and clumsy walk-back effort will cost him. See link... https://edition.cnn.com/2022/03/27/politics/joe-biden-vladimir-putin-ukraine-war/index.html
I am anticipating a rise (albeit temporary?) within the next 5 weeks. For now, it seems almost implausible for a drastic drop below 40.
Question is closing!
Something significant breaking loose in Ukraine will affect his approval rating for better or worse. But there's only a few days left for his current rating to change.
Following the crowd instead of researching :(

With only a week to go, not much change likely. However, oil and gasoline prices are rising (and natural gas) which will engender more discontent. Aside that the president has zero impact on O&G prices, discontent means lowered approval. Also missing in discontent is any understanding of O&G ... year(s) to bring on more US production, even if wells drilled and not completed. (A canard is the federal leasing moratorium created a shortfall however, leases to production is even longer, and federal acreage left is not very prospective ... and not much federal in the Permian, Williston (Bakken), S Texas (Eagle Ford). You decide on O&G but learn about it rather than listen to politicians from either party.

Given that there is little rational thinking in US politics and people simply base their opinions on whether someone is a Democrat or Republican, there really isn’t a need to justify my opinion or rationale for this prediction. ;)

Looking at all pollsters' sites the average score is 41,67; while looking at past presidents it shows that they all have a decline at more or less a year after. With an exception on GWB due to the events during his presidency. Given the present crisis, he may stay above 40%.
At the time of this forecast FiveThirtyEight has his approval sitting at 41.8%. With a week left it seems statistically a certainty he will end up in the 2nd bucket.
Getting the common war bounce.
Its only a few days and he is hovering in the low 40s.
As of 23 March, Biden's approval rating is 41.5%. The lowest so far this year is 40.4% on 27 Feb. The most recent highest (above 45%) is 45.3% in Sept 2021,

Despite a post-state of the union jump, President Biden is back around 42%. Events in Ukraine could swing him up or down, but I'm increasing my odds for 40 to 45% given the nearness of the question's end date.
the possibilities for bin shifts are narrowing as time runs down CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py
Almost no policy or plans have been put into place and I'd say that people aren't supportive of the handling of global affairs currently (fairly or unfairly).
All in. Only 10 days left to go. Very large, fast jumps in approval rating are exceedingly unlikely.

The US is very polarized, largely due to Russian disinformation and money. There is at least 34% of the population that will never support Biden or any other Democrat with another 12% that claim to be independents and are closet Republicans - they too will never support a Democrat. Likely maximum positive rating for Biden is 52%
@Dillyweed - your forecast matches my simulation almost exactly!

2.5 weeks left. If something big and unexpected happened in the world today, it would probably take longer than this for much of the US public to even hear about it or think it through seriously enough to blame/credit Biden for it (it’s what happens when you primarily get your news third-hand from TikTok influencers and reality TV shows). Approval is still basically mid-bin #2 and increasingly difficult to see that change in the remaining time window, given how robustly approval rates have stuck where they are over the past months.

incremental change from my previous forecast as time runs and the existing bin becomes more likely. Informed by a Monte Carlo simulation. CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py
The answer to this question hinges mainly on action in Ukraine and the US inflation rate.
Biden's approval has remained in the 40-45% range for the past 5 1/2 months. It's unlikely to exit that range in the next 19 days.
incremental change from my previous forecast as time runs and the existing bin becomes more likely.
He's smack in the middle today and barring some major global issue (not that any of those are happening...) he's likely to stay there for the next few weeks
similar reasoning to my previous forecasts. Informed by a simulation. CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py
Narrowing back to 40 to 45 as his approval has bounced back a bit from the recent dip.
Ukraine bump looking like rating will sit firmly above 40%, but still unsure of more climbs in 3 weeks...

Given most recent 538 polls I think the crowd is under-rating the chances that his approval breaks above 45. Russia/Ukraine is a very dynamic situation and rally around the flag effect can cause very fast polling changes. Of course there's also inflation and other pains that could push approval down or counterweight. Overall, I upped my 40-45 chances, though, and shifted some chance from below 40 to above 45.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/
It's up about 2% in the last few days. . . .at 42.6%

Unstable times always cause a reinforcement of support for an incumbent. However I don’t think this will be large for Biden given the way US politics is at the moment. It’s probably enough to keep his support above 45pc until end of March, with a small change to go over 50pc, but unlikely.

February job numbers much better than expected. While inflation remains high and implications of Ukrainian situation continues to present uncertainty in gasoline and energy markets, continuing progress in other economic metrics seem to be holding up.

Reverting closer to a previous forecast. Seems that the recent big downward jump was a short-term fluctuation and that we are now back to our ‘regularly scheduled approval-rate programming’. Well over a percentage point of buffer, extreme stability of approval rates over the past months (in spite of everything going on) and only weeks to go now -> high confidence forecast.
There's been another uptick in Biden's approval rating in recent days. A random walk from here indicates that he ends up with lower than 40% only about 22% of the time.

Biden's approval rating as of this forecast is sitting near an all time low of 41.1% while in the midst of what is (hopefully) the tail end of COVIDs pandemic phase, the initial blitz of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the highest inflation we have seen in decades, sky high oil costs, and major stock indices in either correction(Dow, S&P500) or Bear market (Nasdaq) territory.
Interested to see if there is a bounce after the state of the union or change due to Ukraine.

In his latest forecast @Ryan-Beck , makes a good point that Biden may take the blame with voters if things go badly in Ukraine [1] . I ran a quick simulation [2] and a random walk in approval ratings suggests that Biden will end up under 40% about a third of the time given today's approval rating of 40.8%.

Decided to go to even more on below 40. It's still early in the Russian invasion so there's some hope for Ukraine, but I think a month from now the most likely scenario is that Russia will have captured Kyiv. And people tend to blame the president for every bad turn of events, so I don't think that bodes well for his approval rating
Going up a bit on sub 40.

One month left on the question. Economic consequences seem to be driving the approval rating. Ukraine invasion and anticipated FED action on interest rates in March would seem to likely keep inflation high. Surprise approval might come from Ukrainian withholding against invasion and US actions looking like a win.
https://www.yahoo.com/news/bidens-job-approval-hits-low-200104759.html
Gas prices will go up, and Biden will be blamed.

Slight adjustment towards uncertainty here. The picture hasn’t changed much but Ukraine raises the possibility of a shift in either direction as the next month is simply hard to predict https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-will-americans-grade-bidens-handling-of-the-crisis-in-ukraine/
Feb 25, 2022 approval rating has dropped to 40.8%. Between now and March 31, 2022, the likelihood of events which may lead to an increase in approval rating is very low in my opinion.
Increasing expected approval rating based on typical approvals increasing in crises, in response to Ukraine
Handling of Russian actions make me point to lower rating probability.
There's been a steep uptick in Biden's approval rating in recent days. A random walk from here indicates that he ends up with lower than 40% only about 12% of the time.

Re-balancing increasingly low probability assigned to outcomes outside of bin #2. This reflects a recent small increase in approval ratings: Biden’s back to the ~center of bin #2 so now giving equal weight to bins #1 and #3. Just a few weeks to go now, with the US public as polarized as ever. Recent stability of approval rates in spite of inflation, omicron, etc. gives much confidence in the status quo.
Fixed prior forecast - didn't factor in probability of staying in current band

Current approval rating: 42.3% approve, trending slightly upwards https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/ Historical trends: - Lower than 40% approval appears to have been rare in recent US history - Rare that approvals have gone above initial approval - mostly seems driven by war times e.g. Bush after Sep 11
Ukraine crisis presents uncertainty here for either side of 40-45, so i adjusted for increased variability as it persists.
Narrowing on 40 to 45.
Biden seems helpless over Ukraine and isn't getting his domestic agenda passed. I still think it will end up in the 40-45 range, but dropping below 40 is a real possibility.
Adjusting slightly based on the Monte Carlo simulation with pretty much the same ideas as my previous forecasts [1] for my "inside view".
Persistent Russian issue and continued likelihood of initiatives falling short along with mid-terms pushing prospects of anything beyond 45% a low probability.

The US political scene is extremely polarized. Currently, they have excellent job growth and strong prospects going forward. Industry is responding to Chinese competition and ‘re-shoring’. The Infrastructure spending will start to kick in next year. Inflation globally is showing 5-6% annual rates and may climb, whether this is transitory or part of a longer term trend is unclear but the US is no worse than the global figures. Covid is yielding, slowly, to vaccines and now therapeutics. With this generally positive outlook there should be strong support for the government and Biden. It is not the case and polarization is the only explanation.
If Russia invades Ukraine that increases the variance on estimates of bidens popularity.

Depends on pandemic, inflation, and Biden's actions. Problem for him is he is slow to change, resistive to exiting the traditional Party mindset PLUS he is being pushed by the progressive left who aren't helping him any, preferring to win ideologically and relinquish winning elections (either that or self delusion the country is overwhelminly with them ... even if true, it is those who vote who count). There is also the matter of timing. He doesn't have much time and it's hard to see much changing in less than 7 weeks. 40% is about it.
Kid vax debacle and continued inflation could cause it to drop further; wag the dog Ukraine stuff could rally people to him in the short term

Passage of time. Biden’s rating is about as low as we’ve seen, but there seems to be a floor at this level, and we’re still basically 1/4 of a bin away from the boundary. Given how stable public opinion has been, and how long it tends to be before it changes, I’m feeling increasingly confident that we will see the Question resolve in bin #2. Outside credible chance that some new disaster or scandal could take us to bin #1, e.g. Ukraine, etc. but I don’t think it’s likely to matter enough, soon enough in the current hyper-polarized political climate.
Currently at 41.2, and I guess more dissatisfaction coming mainly due to inflation.
It seems there was a sudden drop in Biden's approval rating today. I ran a quick simulation and made my "inside view" adjustments as with my previous forecasts [1].

When Russia invades Ukraine, and the US sends some more troops to coordinate allies and support the effort, I don't think this will increase his popularity, as many people seem to see the Ukraine situation as not very relevant to the US. (I believe it is very relevant; that's just my impression of what many think.) So I'm tilting my forecast very slightly lower than the crowd's.
Updating my guess, betting heavily that declining Omicron numbers will stop the fall in Biden's popularity. Admittedly it could be close to the 40% breakpoint. Less than 8 weeks to go.
It's all about the economy. Which will be worse in March
Adjusting slightly based on the Monte Carlo simulation with pretty much the same ideas as my previous forecasts [1] for my "inside view".

Going up 5 on below 40, Omicron wave is declining so that may help him but there's also Russia and inflation that I think are probably hurting him in the eyes of respondents currently and will probably be ongoing through March.

The omicron variant appears to be on the decline and the expected retirement of Justice Breyer will give a chance for President Biden to fulfill a campaign promise (with a nomination likely to be underway sometime around the March 1 State of the Union, is my guess). Gallup shows that most presidents don't swing wildly in their approval ratings from January to March, however. So my prediction is that there will be a slight upward trend to the current president's numbers, but nothing outrageous (keeping in mind that President Biden has never topped 55% approval according to fivethirtyeight).

Raising bin 2 based on Supreme court pick to be confirmed soon (probably). Also if we presume poll numbers are linked to COVID cases, even in small part, decreasing cases would bump up polls a little.

Difficult question, but the past two presidents' track record in year two of their mandate within this timeframe indicates a relatively steady approval rating. Big current events that could impact one way or the other include Russia, inflation/fed rates, SCOTUS nomination, and persistence of COVID/restrictions are what I see. These events are likely to be weighed differently, but most have more to lose than gain as I see it (for now).

The Monte Carlo simulation hasn't changed much from my previous forecast [1], but adjusting down on my "inside view" for bin 3 due to the emergence of Omicron BA.2 which will probably mean covid is front and center in people's minds for longer than I originally anticipated.

Since taking office, country is more divided than it has been in decades. Inflation is high, invasion of illegal immigrants continues daily; the pulling out of troops in Afghanistan; lack of respect for media outlets in regards to answering questions; weak “negotiations” with Putin; possibility of deploying military in response to threat of war from Russia on Ukraine; seeming to be completely unaware of travesty of his actions; getting involved and making comments on Rittenhouse case before anyone had any evidence proving this young man’s innocence.; the numbers of Senate that are retiring or moving away from the Democratic Party; defund the police movement and not taking action to restore civility; mandates of Covid vaccine; his ignorance or lack of courage, of what it takes to hold the office of President in United States. I could continue with listing his many failures, however, it would be as long, if not longer, that the rap sheets of criminals allowed to roam our country.
Pet the new cat and say it ain't so, Joe. And he will do exactly that.

I expect President Biden's numbers to improve a bit as the focus shifts to the Supreme Court nomination. He may also get a small bump from the State of the Union speech. Much like Trump and Obama he seems to have a pretty solid floor of support around 40%. The ebbing of the Omicron wave should help as well. Russia and Ukraine seem like pure downside risk.
The momentum downwards is too great to reverse. Fauci's indictment coming soon might sink them all. Ukraine's agenda will sink him into this territory for good.

Updating again since Biden's approval has risen to 41.7% (the better part of a percentage point). A Monte Carlo simulation of a random walk based on previous approval shifts suggests that, from today's 41.7% approval rating, Biden's approval has a ~26% of landing in bin 1 and a ~12% chance of landing in bin 3 [1], so I'll continue to take this as my "outside view". My "inside view" remains pretty much the same as my earlier forecast [2], but I still think it's possible that other problems outside of covid (e.g. Russia, inflation) will continue to cause problems for Biden's approval numbers. [1] https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py [2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1388060
On the + side is if Biden nominates a candidate for the SCOTUS that excites everyone.

I think the crowd median is a biased representation. I keep seeing rationales that find reasons that would bump up the rating and rarely see ones that call for the downgrading of Biden's approval rating. Perhaps my forecast is too low for bin 2, but I think some middleground between mine and the current median is appropriately acceptable.

Updating slightly from my last forecast as Biden's approval has fallen to 41.0%. A Monte Carlo simulation of a random walk based on previous approval shifts suggests that, from today's 41.0% approval rating, Biden's approval has a ~35% of landing in bin 1 and a ~7.5% chance of landing in bin 3 [1], so I'll continue to take this as my "outside view". My "inside view" remains pretty much the same as my previous forecast [2], but I do think it's possible that other problems outside of covid (e.g. Russia, inflation) will continue to cause problems for Biden's approval numbers. I changed forecast for the Roe question and by the same logic I will with this one. I think the Breyer retirement will only bump up poll ratings
Seems to be sliding downward recently.

Downward pressures The media seems to have concluded that Biden is, at best, a lack-luster POTUS. COVID fatigue If there's any problems distributing the masks or tests if there's a new COVID variant if there's war with Russia over Ukraine--this could also work in is favor if more ICBMs are fired by DPRK if China becomes more aggressive in the So & East China Sea & there's a crisis over Taiwan--this could also work in is favor if we get into deeper involvement in Saudi Arabia's war in Yemen--this could also work in is favor if there's a massive decline in the stock market if inflation increases if there's rising interest rates if there's another stampede of immigrants along our southern border

A Monte Carlo simulation of a random walk based on previous approval shifts suggests that, from today's 41.3% approval rating, Biden's approval has a ~30% of landing in bin 1 and a ~10% chance of landing in bin 3 [1], so I'll take this as my "outside view". As for my "inside view", I generally agree with @jleibowich 's last comment [2] that falling covid cases will likely bolster Biden's approval rating. Also, as per @Anneinak 's previous comments, it would be rare for a president to have an approval rating less than 40% this early on although Biden is close now and it did happen for Clinton and Trump [3]. His approval rating has been declining, but I'm hesitant to bet too heavily on Bin 1 because I figure COVID will most likely have reached endemicity by late March, so I could realistically see his approval rating start to go up again as people feel more more content about their lives returning to normal.
raising bin 1 9%: Blinken ordering diplomats and their families to leave Ukraine due to Russia chicanery certainly wouldn't make poll numbers go up... https://apple.news/A-NDzahAMQHGclKe33yxK3A

Inflation and volatility on the rise, as well as oil prices, and serious geopolitical conflict brewing (which the opposition is clearly and openly using to attack Dems and the Biden admin even if that means taking the side of a foreign enemy power). Next few months will be a big stress test for the POTUS. He's not a big salesman of his accomplishments or his agenda as his predecessor was and the public has gotten accustomed to that in the way our world communicates and interacts today. The press also has proven not as friendly as it seems to be more interested in clicks and engagement which is more often than not a result of controversy, conflicting, exposes. Much of the US press has evolved into not just a partisan arm but also business entities and ideological bodies whose jobs is to dig for the dirt, the flaw, the crooked, negative aspect of any issue. That seems to be the focus of reporting. Biden's demeanor itself in a time where drum wars are sounding do not help when put in comparison to an opponent that sells the image Putin does. October, November may paint a different picture for Biden but I think March is more challenging.

Currently 41.9% with a slight downward trajectory. But still much closer to mid-bin than to the bottom of bin #2. Because of the polarized nature of US politics, there seem to be more ways for the approval rating to stabilize or increase vs significantly decrease from here.

He's headed south (lower today than ever) and the weather forecast isn't good: lower # of new hires expected, inflation increasing, interest rates going up, stock market going down, Manchin & Sinema running the legis agenda & keeping it stalled, threat of war in Ukraine, looking tired/lacking charisma, Harris is not winning him points . . . .

A slight increase in the downside risk - my hypothesis is even if the approval rating dips below 40% temporarily, it will very quickly bounce back. Because this rating matters for mid-terms and hence one should expect the white house machinery to be firing on all cylinders and that should have at least a *small* effect. In other words, I believe there may be a rather *firm* floor.

Nine of the ten previous presidencies bottomed out at under 40% on Gallup at some point. If the Ukraine is invaded, or if another variant pops up, or inflation increases, Biden’s short-term numbers will collapse.
I'm highly skeptical. Just overlaying some of the previous presidential trends onto the Biden trend brings it in the upper 30s to lower 40s, which means the first bin isn't too far a stretch.
things are not looking good in Europe: Ukraine Fed may raise interest rates, causing stock market to dive
Update with passage of time

Definitely a downward trend overall. At the same time of their presidencies, both Trump and Obama increased ever so slightly, so that's what I think it's kind a toss up between lower40 and 40-45. 4% for rebounding above 45%. Only some great news in the next 2 months will budge the number up that quickly, hard to imagine what that news would be.

Biden's approval on FiveThrtyEight is at 42.0% this morning. A random walk in approval ratings from here based on Biden's approval movement history means getting back above 50% by the end of March is now at less than half a percent in the Monte Carlo simulations. Meanwhile, it puts the "Lower than 40.0%" bucket is at ~23%. While a president going below 40% this early would be unusual, Trump was at around 35% [1] after his first year, so it would not be unprecedented. I'm still biasing on the positive side of what the Monte Carlo simulation suggests based on my suspicion that as Omicron abates, Biden's approval numbers will improve.
Thinking about @JonathanMann's forecast @https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1384197 . . . .

The last three Democrats had almost a 60% approval rating after their first year in office. As of 13 January President Biden's approval rating is ~45%. With looming international issues such as Ukraine-Russia conflict, and China-Taiwan, and what the US is prepared to do, I don't see any event within the next 2.5 months that would make it go up. Because of ongoing COVID testing issues, as one example, I do see a situation where it can easily go down a few more points and perhaps under 40%.

President Biden's current policies are not currently effective at raising the approval rate. Public gaffes by both POTUS and VPOTUS are alienating the public on both sides. Significant issues such as COVID are worsening with no end in sight. As the election season ramps up, Republican attacks will almost certainly have an effect on public opinion among undecided voters.
Adjusting to reflect current polling and the difficult economic environment ahead.

My "inside view" is that by the end of March, within the United States, the Omicron wave will have largely petered out and Biden's poll numbers will improve as a result. My "outside view" is informed by a Monte Carlo simulation based on Biden's previous polling shifts. Putting the two together, I stared from the MC simulation and made minor adjustments to be slightly less bearish than the crowd in my forecast of Biden's approval rating. MC Simulation : { "Lower than 40.0%" : 19.0%, "Between 40.0% and 45.0%, inclusive": 60.66%, "Higher than 45.0% but lower than 50.0%": 19.49%, "Between 50.0% and 55.0%, inclusive": 0.84%, "Higher than 55.0%": 0.01%, } CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py

The odds of some major emergency that hypes UP his approval rating is virtually nil - and a Russian invasion of Ukraine just might tick it down past 40. As we get closer to March 31, the odds of the status quo holding improve.
A really marginal update to B!, increasing the downside risk to 2%.
Failure to pass Build Back Better bill and continuing rise in inflation.
more likely to drop than go up in my view, due to pervasive inflation problems plus the sense of rudderlessness on COVID and, generally, everything.
Passage of time.
I expect the economy to worsen as inflation continues.
Today it is 43.1%

Forecast informed by Monte Carlo simulation mixed with a similar "inside view" to my previous forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351171 CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py
Sinking
43% seems to be the bottom for him unless he does something particularly stupid or suffers some major disaster both of which could happen.

Let's hypothesize that the difference in popular vote between Biden & Trump - which is about 4.5% or let's round it down to 4% as a minimum difference between the approval ratings. Trump's lowest was about 37%, so Biden is very unlikely to dip below 40% and that can be taken as his floor. On the upside, there isn't that much room either - given Omicron's entry which is likely to have a significant impact in the next few months, the Americans aren't likely to feel that charitable - so over 50% is almost ruled out. That leaves B2 and B3, right now, B3 seems very unlikely.
If projections that Omicron will peak by the end of January are correct, we could be in a much better place at the end of March. That could boost, or at least stop the fall of Biden's popularity.

Up till now Biden's approval rating is higher than Trump's after the same number of days and lower than Obama's rating. So, around day 436 of his presidency, he still will be higher than Trump (40.5%) and lower than Obama (47.7%). The numbers rarely go below 40% within a year of presidency, except for Trump. Who was by all accounts an outlier. Unless, there will be a war, the rating will not be above the 55%.

It's often said that a POTUS approval rating rises in times of war. Biden is facing low approval for management of current Covid wave and could very well be facing upcoming turmoil in international policy regarding Russia and Ukraine. There is currently 55% disapproval of handling of the pandemic and 60% disapproval for his handling of the economy. 538 current approval rating is at 43%. Othe outlets show him slightly higher at 44-45%.

Barring a specific trigger event that would affect the president's standing, I believe the primary driver will be everyone's perception of inflation. Wages are rising but so is inflation. The Fed projects a slight rise from 2.2 to 2.6% but Republicans and conservative media will make much of this, convincing everyone they are worse off because of the Biden economic program.

Forecast informed by Monte Carlo simulation mixed with a similar "inside view" to my previous forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351171 CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/biden_approval/biden_monte_carlo.py

The current approval rate is ~43%. When the Infrastructure Bill is finally passed, the approval rate will likely go up. However, there are a lot of COVID and China-related issues that are likely to keep ratings lower than 50%.

Biden's approval rating has been more stable than I expected these past two months, but I think there is a chance of it declining over the the next couple of months as many Americans get fed up with federal precautions for handling omicron (potential domestic travel vaccine mandate, etc.).
Updating with passage of time, using a probability distribution based on approval rating change data from Trump through Carter.

Updating my forecast a bit given passage of time (closer to deadline) along with potential shutdowns/lockdowns alongside spikes in Omicron cases. Probable failure of Build-Back-Better bill will keep his approval rating lower too, though Senator Manchin is the one taking most of the heat for that.

It's holding pretty steady on 42.5 recently, narrowing around that a bit.

No change in my estimate despite changes in the group's average. The administration is contending with several negative topics, Continuing Resolution can was kicked from December to February, Debt limit looking in mid December, part two of the budget/infrastructure bill, Russian troop movements near Ukraine, and the emergence of COVID Omicron. However, each of these also presents an opportunity to demonstrate problem solving. And he probably only needs to have positive results in one or two of those areas while holding ground in others to keep overall approval ratings in the 45-50% range.

Adjusting for passage of time, and to account for the near-flat approval ratings trend over the past month. Current rating is basically straight in the middle of bin #2. I strongly expect the status quo to continue (new effects on public opinion caused by inflation, covid, economic uncertainty would be offset with a perception of legislative progress and/or any unexpected good news in my current most likely scenario). Significant new bad news or new recognition by the public of the current administration’s basic competence and decency could still cause significantly better or worse outcomes.
Expecting a flat rate for the upcoming months. More legislation expected to pass in early 2022, will help sway supporters. If there’s a decrease in CPI/ inflation it will help bump numbers up.

Shy of something extraordinary right around the end of March, I believe that for quite some time, any President's approval rating will hover around 45%, outside bumps or dives based on short term events and fluctuations. Essentially there's a little over 40% that will always support, a little over 40% that will always disapprove, and about 8% that will move based on actual performance.
Oh my God these sliders suck
Inflation, inflation
The terrible performance of the economy will disappointed everyone in USA.Especially when the economic crisis outbreak.

Biden's current numbers are 42.8%. His high was 55.1%. By March, the supply chain issues should have been resolved and the second infrastructure bill should have been signed. Unless an unpredicted event occurs, the most contentious issue will likely be inflation. Although Carter received a 19% approval rating in 1979 due to inflation, succeeding presidents never again saw such low numbers.

Moderating further toward the crowd based on the "inside view" that several events recently broke in Biden's favor. I also want to see what will happen with the bills he's backing. My "outside view" is still largely informed by the simulation as described in my previous comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351171

For my "outside view", my simulation of a random walk in approval ratings suggests the odds are as follows: "Lower than 40.0%": 25% "Between 40.0% and 45.0%, inclusive": 44.25% "Higher than 45.0% but lower than 50.0%": 25.75% "Between 50.0% and 55.0%, inclusive": 4.5% "Higher than 55.0%": 0.5% For my "inside view", I'm trying to balance considerations such as whether Biden has a support floor / ceiling and also whether there are limiting factors on how far his support can move in either direction due to partisanship. I suspect his ceiling is in the high 50's under normal circumstances although extraordinary events could change this. Meanwhile, I suspect his floor is somewhere in the lower 30's under normal circumstances. With that said, it may be harder and harder to move toward the extremes of this range as each layer of additional change is more difficult to move than the previous. For that reason, I'm giving the 40-45 and 45-50 buckets significantly higher weight than the random walk simulation would suggest. Adjusting probabilities to account for a few comparative observations (new to me, apologies in advance to those who've already been watching things very carefully for a long time): - Biden's "August Slide" downwards may not be completely over, but in the past few weeks seems to have slowed significantly / stabilized, with the ultimate low perhaps to be expected in the ~43-44% range (if it goes lower without first rebounding upwards significantly, that would suggest the slide isn't yet over after all at the time of this forecast). - The previous president had a remarkably flat and stable approval rating, in spite of a near-continuous string of bad news / good news (depending on the kind of news channel followed). The news flow from that presidency--because of its seriousness and impact on a variety of major issues (foreign, domestic, economic, etc.)--almost certainly included some events that would've very likely caused much more significant swings in pre-2000's US public opinion. The presidency before that also had a very low amount of variation in approval ratings, although arguably there were far fewer "shocks" to the political system. - The trends of Biden's and Obama's approval ratings during the first year of their respective presidencies seem visually fairly similar. Perhaps one reference scenario to keep an eye on might be: "Evolution of Biden's approval ratings will closely track those of Obama's, but be offset downwards by 6-7%"...

Approval rating should probably stay within a fairly narrow range (middle three bins) if no extraordinary events occur shortly before 31 March 2022. Even if a significant event or two did occur several months ahead of this date that caused a large up- or down-swing in the approval rating, I would intuitively expect public opinion in our highly polarized US political climate to slowly return to a “normal” level over time.

Since 1953, approval ratings for the 12 US Presidents prior to Biden have ranged from a high of 70.1% to a low of 41.1%. Ratings: <40% = 0, 40 – 45% = 1, >45 – <50% = 5, 50 – 55 % = 1, >55% = 5 Average Rating: 53.26. Average Democrat Rating: 56.45 If President Kennedy is removed from evaluation, average is 53.72.

Keeping the spirit of my old forecast but factoring in some of the forecasters' confidence in an approval rating of greater than 45%.

Presidential approval ratings are increasingly a market of partisan identity moreso than actual personal evaluation of Presidential job performance. The odds that many people who voted for Biden will relinquish their approval of him seems low. That said, approval numbers often tend to dip below midterms.

Barring something completely unexpected, President Biden will likely have about the same approval rating through at least the next 6 months. When you look at historic trends in Presidential approval rating, they generally stay within a range of 5 to 10 points over a similar period of time, again barring crisis or significant events to shape American opinion.

I don't see where Biden's numbers go up from here. Passing more legislation will probably just invite more backlash. Republicans will be starting to gear up attack ads to run against him during the midterms (and not just the Dem party). There will likely be more bad news from Afghanistan. The media seems on hair-trigger alert to criticize the Biden admin now since Afghanistan (the Biden admin also seems curiously bad at diplomacy more generally, see the reaction to the UK-AUS-US submarine deal). There will likely be more health problems and issues with VP Harris. All told, I don't see approval drifting up over 50% and it very well could go lower than 40%.

I'm guessing the inflation/Afghanistan/Delta stuff will have faded some by resolution next year, so I think the current dip is semi-temporary. That said it looks like the trend is a slow decline, so I'm guessing Biden will have a slight bounce back followed by a steady decline which I'm guessing will be similar to Obama's trend.

Biden support even after the Afghanistan withdrawal has not dropped below 45pc and it already looks like his approval is increasing again. This suggests to me that there may be a floor in support around 45pc. I can’t see support going over 55pc, so the mostly likely think is it will hover in the 45 to55pc range. I’m weighting slightly on the 45-50pc range on the assumption that people are more likely to be disappointed in Biden regardless.

In terms of extremes, could Biden slip below 40%? Given recent issues with vaccinations, Delta and now Afghanistan, his popularity has certainly waned, but equally 45% could now be factoring in most of the bad news, and I think he'll recover some ground after bottoming out around 42% (I can't see him being less popular than Trump). Above 55%? Obama struggled with this after a brief 'honeymoon' period above 60% and I think Biden may follow a similar but less extreme pattern; he's not as charismatic, but equally my impression is that he's not as polarising, and he's walking quite a tight path to achieve any gains, so I think his popularity may stay in a narrower band. Politics seems even more divided now than when Obama started, so anything much above 50% within 6 months looks ambitious. As for the middle ground, a lot will likely depend on the economy and the fading Delta curve through the end of the year. Barring another new covid variant, political upturn or war (which covers quite a lot, fair enough) I suspect everyone will feel slightly more positive into next Spring and he'll be rated marginally higher than now.

The most striking thing about Biden’s approval ratings is the degree of partisan polarization.

So from day 234 to day 436... Obama dropped ~3% and continued to slide until end of year 2; Bush had a big 9/11 jump then slid; Clinton jumped 10% before sliding again; HW slid unless there was a war; Reagan slid ~6%; Carter slid ~6%. Broadly speaking, unless there's a war or terrorist attack, he's probably going to slide 3-6%. Democratic presidents seem less likely to start something, so that's less likely. The only real hope for an upswing is that the pessimism around Afghanistan is over by then (short attention spans and all). Past that; it's the economy, stupid. Markets are riding high and cracks are showing, both economically and with pandemic response, pretty much on a global scale. I'm not optimistic things will be better in 6 months than they are now, so it's most likely he'll slide. Frankly, from an outside perspective, he seems to be falling a bit flat and that doesn't bode well for his approval rating either. Recent history indicates that a more polarized electorate is more critical, so he'll probably be below historical averages regardless. I'll go ~60% in the 40-45 box and think its more likely to be above than below, then will weight out from there.

By then the Afghanistan thing will be forgotten, which puts upward pressure on his approval ratings over time. The Covid situation should also be significantly better. It's unknowable what future crises are coming, of course. But assuming I'm right on the Afghanistan thing and Covid, the natural partisan leanings of Americans should put Biden back into the 50-55 range.
